data.title: Library Guides at University of Missouri Libraries
data.meta_description: Links to government publications which show consumer prices for common household items or
data.text:
Tip: The most common Black occupations are listed in the U. S. Census report Negroes in the U.S. (1904) page 58, and in Negro labor in the U.S. 1850-1925, pp. 315-319.

Wages of male and female Negroes by occupation - Massachusetts, 1903

Source: Social and industrial condition of the Negro in Massachusetts.

Black cooks in the South earned $4-$6 per month

in 1902

Earnings of African-Americans (1890-1920) discussed in book The Negro wage earner by Lorenzo J. Greene (c1930)

Agricultural work, pp. 65-74.

Building trades, pp. 186-197.

Domestic and personal service, pp. 75-99.

Labor - excavating for public works, p. 166.

Trades and transportation workers, pp. 100-123.

Manufacturing and mechanical pursuits, pp. 124-144.

Mechanics and artisans, p. 174.

Oystermen, pp. 162-163.

Tobacco factories, pp. 152-153.

Source for data below: Employees and Wages, a special report in the 12th Census.

Bakeries - Wages for females in 1890 and 1900

Breweries - Wages for females in 1890 and 1900

Unless otherwise noted, the sources for data below came from Employees and Wages, a special report in the 12th Census, and Report on condition of woman and child wage-earners in the U.S, Dept. of Labor.

Rolling cigars at home in 1908. Most earned less than $8/ week.

Nurses, visiting - Salaries by state, 1909

Includes a directory of organizations that employ visiting nurses, along with salaries paid to them. Use the table of contents to find a state. Source: Visiting nursing in the United States... by Y. Waters, (1909).

Quotable fact: In the 1900-1909 decade, less than 5% of people age 18-21 attended college. Source: U.S. Bureau of Education.
